[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Derive: Eq, PartialEq] [Hash collision] Can attackers craft different NodeInformationResponse values that compare equal but have different semantic meanings, bypassing deduplication or caching logic? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Error: UnexpectedResponseError] [Error message size] Can the error message String in UnexpectedResponseError grow unbounded if the response label or description is attacker-controlled, causing memory exhaustion? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Error: UnexpectedResponseError] [Error propagation] Are UnexpectedResponseError instances properly bounded in error-handling code, or can cascading errors cause stack overflow or infinite error loops? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Function: get_num_bytes()] [Silent failure] If bcs::to_bytes() fails during get_num_bytes(), is the error properly propagated, or could silent failures cause incorrect size accounting and quota bypass? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Struct: NetworkInformationResponse] [Eclipse attack enabler] Can an attacker provide fake connected_peers data that causes honest nodes to preferentially connect to attacker-controlled peers, enabling eclipse attacks that isolate victims from the honest network? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Struct: NodeInformationResponse] [State sync poisoning] Can reporting false highest_synced_epoch and highest_synced_version values trick nodes into syncing from a malicious peer serving forked blockchain data? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Struct: LatencyPingResponse] [Latency manipulation] Can an attacker selectively respond to latency pings with manipulated ping_counter values to artificially lower their measured latency and increase their peer selection priority? (High)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Struct: ConnectionMetadata] [Validator impersonation] Can a compromised fullnode claim peer_role as Validator to intercept consensus messages or participate in voting, potentially disrupting consensus if not properly authenticated? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Struct: ServerProtocolVersionResponse] [Version fork] Can disagreement about protocol versions between peers lead to network fragmentation where nodes refuse to communicate, causing unintentional network splits? (High)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Struct: NodeInformationResponse] [Memory exhaustion] Can an attacker send NodeInformationResponse with extremely large build_information maps (thousands of key-value pairs with long strings) to exhaust memory on receiving nodes? (High)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Struct: NetworkInformationResponse] [CPU exhaustion] Can processing a NetworkInformationResponse with tens of thousands of connected_peers entries cause excessive CPU usage in BTreeMap operations, degrading node performance? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Function: get_num_bytes()] [Serialization cost] Can an attacker repeatedly request get_num_bytes() on large responses to force expensive BCS serialization operations, creating a CPU-based DoS vector? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Struct: NodeInformationResponse] [Temporal inconsistency] Can a peer report ledger_timestamp_usecs from the past while claiming current highest_synced_version, causing confusion in time-dependent protocol logic? (High)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Struct: NodeInformationResponse] [Epoch-version mismatch] Can mismatched highest_synced_epoch and highest_synced_version create state confusion where nodes think they're synced to different epochs, disrupting consensus? (High)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Struct: NetworkInformationResponse] [Distance inconsistency] Can multiple peers report conflicting distance_from_validators values for the same network topology, enabling distance-based routing attacks? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Function: get_num_bytes()] [TOCTOU race] Is there a time-of-check-time-of-use race between calling get_num_bytes() for quota checking and actually sending the response, allowing quota bypass through size changes? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Enum: PeerMonitoringServiceResponse] [Response amplification] Can an attacker request small LatencyPing requests but receive large NetworkInformationResponse by exploiting type confusion, creating an amplification attack? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Struct: NetworkInformationResponse] [Topology mapping] Can aggregating NetworkInformationResponse from multiple peers allow an attacker to reconstruct the complete network graph, including private validator connections? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Struct: NodeInformationResponse] [Zero values] Can a peer legitimately report all zero values (epoch=0, version=0, timestamp=0) at genesis, or would this be misinterpreted as invalid state requiring validation? (Low)
